review_blob: 12 oz. bottle into tulip glass. Decent IPA. Bitter, full bodied. Cant find anything especially interesting about it. My first Goose Island beers were Matilda and Pere Jacques many years ago, so you do the math. Tough to compare. I expect more out of Goose Island.

On draft at Tired Hands. This is what I typically look for in a saison, however not spectacular. A little more peppery and hefty than the Farm Hands Saison. Had a few of these and enjoyed them. Didnt get the flavors of all of the spices but still registered in the saison category.
On draft at Tired Hands. Not as good as I expected. Too light bodied. Tasted like the second runnings of a saison. Not enough there for me.

On draft at Monks Cafe; I almost have to rate this twice; served way too cold on draft, it took 20 minutes to have any flavor; previously enjoyed from bottle served properly, it was delicious; this time, after warming had more of what I was looking for; a little tart (God, I could go for a little tart right now!), medium to full bodied; "bready" aroma.

11.2oz bottle poured into tulip glass; pure Belgian deliciousness; I dont know why the bitch is mad -  Im not after thoroughly enjoying a couple; beautiful pale color; sharp up front; dry; maybe its more like a typical tripel as it ages, but not now; more like a Belgian strong ale.
Very nice. Had one just after enjoying a Victory Hop Devil. Hop Devil much meatier, but this was just as tasty. Fairly aromatic, with great color. Mouthfeel excellent.

25.4 oz. bottle. To my nose, aroma was almost exclusively of cherries, with a little alcohol thrown in. Looked gorgeous in the glass, a fine red/brown color with a haziness that spoke of the tartness that awaited. Small pinkish head that disappeared almost as quickly as it formed. Taste was somewhat one dimensional (tart cherries of course); however, I did detect the distinct taste of fig. Dry on the palate. I took my time drinking the bottle so as to not overwhelm myself with the cherry taste. Overall, I liked it and would recommend it for splitting with another person after dinner.

On tap at Capones, Norristown, PA. Pours opaque black with small tan head that really sticks to glass. Aroma of burnt toast, dark chocolate, some pine, caramel. Dark and meaty. Medium bodied with somewhat pasty finish. Great accompaniment to the crab cakes I ate.

On draft at Capones, Norristown, PA. Pours opaque dark brown, with consistent tan head.  Aroma is of coffee and chocolate; taste is dark chocolate sweet with bitterness in finish; perfect texture for a stout; good beer to slurp; be careful because alcohol can really sneak up on you.

On draft at TJs Everyday, Paoli, PA. Superb sour ale. Poured the color of dark tea, with very minimal head that disappears completely. Wonderful aromas of oak, barnyard, vinegar, sour cherry, and toast.  Aromas strengthened and multiplied as beer warmed. Terrific body. Astringent finish. Alcohol content completely imperceivable.

On draft at The Drafting Room, Spring House, PA. Aroma is of grassy hops and toasted malt. Maybe a little bread in there also. Color is a little too orange, with a minimal white head. Taste is fairly sweet, with the alcohol way too forward. Not tight and refreshing, like a Dortmunder.

On draft at The Drafting Room, Spring House, PA. Short white foamy head that disappears quickly. Beer is clear and apricot in color. Malty aroma, mostly of grains, a little alcohol. Medium sweetness, with some lingering bitterness. Fine texture.

beer_brewer_name: Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake Beer Co.)
review_blob: Ive had this about two dozen times, both on draft and in bottle. I dont know why I keep getting it (maybe because its fairly common at places that dont sell good beers). It looks fine in a glass, but the aroma is pungent (skunked) and the taste is just bad. If I was really thirsty, it probably wouldnt be so bad, but otherwise, no thanks.

On draft at The Belgian Cafe, Philadelphia. Medium-sized tan head over dark brown beer. Coffee aroma. Coffee and chocolate flavors. Mildly bitter. A little too thin-bodied for my taste, but still easily drinkable.

On tap at the Dunedin House of Beer. Good-but-not-great West Coast style IPA. Nothing really differentiates from other beers of the ilk, except maybe a little drier in finish. Its good, but I think my expectations of this were too high to begin with.
beer_name: Cigar City Jai Alai India Pale Ale

review_blob: 750 ml bottle at the Dunedin Brewery. Gorgeous murky apricot color with moderate white head that lingers. Funk, lemon, and slight banana aromas are present. Delicious and thirst-quenching sour taste dominates. Shorter finish than most JP beers. Love it and hope to have it again soon.

Draft at The Belgian Cafe, Philadelphia. Excellent and unusual in flavor and texture. Aroma is sweet, especially of caramel. Also sensed a little tobacco aroma. Thick, foamy white head. Dark brown to black color. Taste is medium sweet with just enough bitterness. Texture is a little "wheaty", if you will. Overall a great beer.

Draft. Good session IPA with mid- to strong-bitterness. Very dry finish. Mild perfumy aroma with some herbal. Medium white head, that disappears except for a ring around the glass. Beautiful amber color, very inviting.

Coors Light used to be my favorite BMC light beer (when I was much younger) but Miller LIte has assumed the position. Youll also likely assume the position - on the toilet bowl that is! Damn, this is some God-awful crap.

Draft at Capones; I hope you like bourbon (I do!); Aroma is of bourbon and vanilla; mouthfeel reminds you that this isnt for the weak of heart; chestnut-like color with no head; contrary to the commercial deScription, I didnt think it was a "sipper"; the faster I drank it, the smoother it got; I would definitely get it again under the right circumstances

Draft at Capones; Another top notch, almost California-style IPA; if it didnt have the "malt backbone" it could really get crazy with the hops; pretty darned bitter in taste, and aromatic up front; for some reason Im getting some booziness throughout; good drinking if youre having a couple, but not more
Bottle; Quite nice; I thought it was dryer than most raters have posted; straw in color, decent head; puckering; very good, but expensive

12 oz. bottle; Ive had this many times, both in bottle and on tap, and love it every time. One of my favorite places to enjoy it is tailgating at Phillies games in the summer. Its a great session IPA and easy to drink. No overwhelming anything, well balanced. Honey-colored beer with a medium-sized, white foamy head. Citrus aroma that just screams "Drink me!" Im more than willing to follow orders. This is a beer made for summer barbecues, but great any time of year.

12 oz. bottle; Not as assertive as the deScription might lead one to believe; nice color and appearance, but mild aroma; bittering hops apparent in the taste but held at bay by a strong malt presence; light bodied; decent IPA; nice finish

Bottle poured into standard pint glass. I have to agree with most raters here: very average beer from a very good brewery. When the question is Southern Tier, the answer is usually "Yes, please!" This is a rare exception. Theres nothing terrible about it, but it really could use an infusion of maltiness. The beer is slightly bitter tasting, not much aroma, and very thin in body.
beer_name: Southern Tier PMX (Phin & Matts Extraordinary Ale)

review_blob: 12 oz bottle poured into a standard pint glass. Dark brown color with a medium tan head. Aroma loaded with molasses, but also coffee and chocolate. Taste is full of molasses and just plain brown-ness (chocolate malts maybe). Somewhat creamy mouthfeel which makes it easy to quaff. Finishes quickly with little aftertaste. Ive had quite a few of these in the past, and plan to do the same in the future. Good session beer.

12 oz. can; gift from a friend; What can I say about this beer? Theres almost nothing to it. Crystal clear, pale yellow color, with a thin white head. Slight aroma of lemon and honey. Tastes about what you would expect. Ive never had a beer with such a short finish. Actually it did make me burp. Maybe it does taste better on the beach in Aruba.

12 oz bottle; Easy drinkin, baby. I must say I find it impossible to believe its almost 8 percent. Tremendous aroma with many components. Dark brown color, clear, leaving a small light tan head. Somewhat sweet and malty taste. Medium to light in body, leaving a pleasant aftertaste.

Maybe someday my dreams will come true and I will be in the employ of Brasserie Dupont.
Poured a golden straw color, with thick foamy white head. Aroma includes yeast, sweet malt, and citrus. Citrus also present in the flavor. Light to medium in body. A nice one to guzzle, in a sophisticated way of course.

Big bottle shared with friends. Always a goodie! Reddish brown, clear pour that leaves a foamy white head that lingers. Sweet malt and alcoholic aroma. Taste is also sweet with some pepper. Medium, chalky body.

Bottle. Gift from a friend that recently drank his way through Belgium.  Moderate bread aroma with some alcohol. Fair amount of frothy white head that really lasted. Clear sparkling golden color. Tastes were acetic, bitter, and a good amount of pepper. Dry finish. Easily conceals its 9 percent.

12 oz. bottle. Ahhh - the first craft beer I ever had, back in 1992. Before that, it was a unending stream of Coors Light, Michelob, Natural Light, an occasional Heineken, and many fifths of Jack Daniels. The first time I had a "Sammy A" (our way of distinguishing it from Samuel Smiths beers back in the day) I couldnt believe the amount of flavor. I was used to water-like beers and soon found out there was no turning back. I still love this beer, with its great malt/hop balance, golden-brown color, medium white head, and light finish. One of the few lagers out there that I will regularly order.
12 oz bottle; Nice enough citrus aroma but thats about the end of it. Almost no flavor at all, watery texture. Doesnt taste bad, just doesnt taste like anything.

750 ml bottle; Pour reveals a brownish-red in color and a thin, white, foamy head. Aroma is of raspberries, sweetness, and a little alcohol. It is much sweeter than any other framboise lambics Ive had. Not one of my favorites.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: 750 ml bottle poured into tulip glass at the Drafting Room, Spring House, PA. Quite good, but what else do you expect from Tomme? Had this today, the hottest and most humid day of the year, so it packed a heck of a wallop. Beautiful dark brown pour with thick foamy head. Definitely syrupy in texture but smooth going down. Reminds me a lot of JPs Madrugada Obscura, but with higher alcohol which is very apparent. Doesnt have JPs mustiness but more of a straight-up stout. Definite recommend!

750 ml bottle. God, I love this beer. I love the fact that its considered a saison, albeit a winter saison. Full bodied without being heavy or cloying, delicious in flavor and appearance. Straw color with a thick white foamy head. Alcohol content is well concealed. I would love to make this a daily drinker.

12.7 oz. bottle. A good, but not great, gueze. Great color - a little orange in the mix. Aroma was lemony but not too intense. This is very dry and somewhat tart. All of the flavor is up front and goes away quickly. However, It did quench my thirst and worked well as an appetizer for my meal. I do like the Cantillon Classic Gueze, Hanssens Oude Gueze and the Boon Oude Geueze quite a bit more.

12 oz. bottle. Another good beer from Great Lakes. Aroma was nice, perfumy and spicy. I didnt taste the honey until late, but the spices and cinnamon are present throughout. More red than copper color, with minimal head. Not as good as Troegs Mad Elf, but still worth the money.

11.2 ml Belgian bottle. Poured a hazy apricot color with small white sudsy head. Aroma is yeasty and full of banana. Flavor is of banana, black pepper, and some sweetness. Slightly soapy mouthfeel. Very easy to drink.

12 oz bottle poured into a standard pint glass. Middle of the road stout. Aroma is mostly coffee and some hop. Pours very dark brown with minimal tan head that quickly dissipates completely. Taste is coffee, with sourness present at the end of the taste.  Medium to light body. Okay beer but nothing to shout about.

From 22 oz. bottle. Intriguing color, somewhat pinkish brown and murky. Small head that dissipated fairly quickly. Aroma is of fruit, not really yeasty. There is nothing lambic about this beer. Strong pepper taste right up front, but which didnt seem so prevalent as the bottle was finished. Good mouthfeel. While the alcohol content was not obvious in the taste or aroma, it sure was shortly afterward. I will give this one another chance in the future.

Poured from a 12.7 oz. bottle into the recommended wine glass.  Very complex beer in that there are several flavors present at any one time and those flavors change throughout the taste. Beer pours a brownish gold, slightly hazy, with a white moderately-sized head. Aromas of hay, moderately yeasty, and some alcohol. Sourness and pepper dominate in the taste, with citrus, dough, and toasted malt accents. Mouthfeel is perfect throughout, exiting with a soapy finish. Just an excellent beer.

beer_brewer_name: Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake Beer Co.)
review_blob: 12 oz bottle poured into a pilsner glass. Many other beers have tried to lay claim to this title, but Leinies Summer Shandy wins it: The Beer For People Who Dont Like Beer. There is almost nothing about it that suggests beer. However, it certainly doesnt taste bad. Pours cloudy straw color, with substantial foamy head that disappears at a medium pace. Mostly lemon in the aroma. Taste is lemony with a strong grape flavor. Light bodied with no hint of alcohol in the taste or aftertaste. Having a glass of very sweet lemonade would have the same effect.

beer_brewer_name: Wild Goose Brewery (Frederick Brewing Company/Flying Dog)
review_blob: Poured from 12 oz bottle to standard pint glass. Minimal white head that dissipates quickly to nothing. Aroma is mostly of pumpkin, while taste is pumpkin and nutmeg. Medium bodied. One of the better pumpkin beers Ive had.

beer_brewer_name: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
review_blob: 12 oz bottle poured into a standard pint glass. Batch 59. Nice beer but could have used a little aging. Aroma was of heavy malt, bread, and alcohol. Beer poured a medium brown, murky, with significant chunks. Good light brown head and lacing. Flavor was fairly bitter up front, but diminished over time while sourness grew. Alcohol somewhat present throughout tasting. This wasnt one of the best barley wine style beers Ive had, but maybe with a little aging it might have been.

beer_brewer_name: Magic Hat Brewing Company (North American Breweries)
review_blob: On tap at The Drafting Room, Spring House, PA. Wow - not good. Color is about as undesirable as possible, being bright red. Not chestnut, not reddish, not hot pink - fire engine red. No head to speak of. Faint aroma of hops. Medium bodied beer that doesnt taste bad, it just doesnt taste like much of anything. Maybe a little sweetness. I dont know what MH was going for, but Im sure it fell short of it.

12 oz bottle poured into standard pint glass. Pour reveals strong amber color, clarity is clear with no particles. Aroma is superb and very inviting; includes strong pine, hop, and light bread notes predominate. Mouthfeel is full bodied, but somehow also a little thin upon finish. Bitterness says mild "IPA", heavier body and mouthfeel says "American Pale Ale."
beer_name: Great Lakes Burning River Pale Ale

review_blob: 12 oz bottle poured into standard pint glass. Its Dogfish Head, so of course you cant expect it to taste as expected. My favorite part was the dry finish and mouthfeel. The pour resulted in an average amount of off-white head that quicly diminished to nothing. Color is light apricot with small and medium sized particulate matter leading to a cloudy look. Kind of a "juice" look. Flavor is really front-loaded and acetic. I really didnt taste peach, actually more like nectarines. Finish flavor is kind of acetic and lemony. I liked this beer quite a bit.

12 oz. bottle poured into a standard pint glass. Another winner from Jolly Pumpkin!  Nice pour with no foam explosion.  Substantial creamy head that never got any thinner than 3/8". It looks like a pure white blanket protecting the beer below, not allowing you to see its goodness even when tilting the glass to drink. Looking at the glass from the side reveals a light straw colored beer, fairly fizzy, and only slightly cloudy. Rarely does a beer look so drinkable. Aroma is yeasty with some citrus. Taste is citrus up front, tart at the end, and yeasty and oaky throughout. Nice dry finish that leaves me wanting more.

12 oz bottle poured into a standard pint glass. Thick foamy pure white head, which leaves some pretty nice lacing.   Aroma was not as heavy as claimed in the commercial deScription, but it definitely was spicy and flowery.  Color is pale gold and slightly hazy.  Taste is very bright with wheat, citrus, and spice.  A little better than most domestic witbiers, and very refreshing.
beer_name: Great Lakes Holy Moses White Ale
